skill.name: ena-database
skill.description: Access European Nucleotide Archive via API/FTP. Retrieve DNA/RNA sequences, raw reads (FASTQ), genome assemblies by accession, for genomics and bioinformatics pipelines. Supports multiple formats.
skill.summary: Access genomic data from the European Nucleotide Archive via REST APIs and FTP for bioinformatics research.
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate bioinformatics data access skill for querying the European Nucleotide Archive. All static findings are false positives. The 'external_commands' detections are backtick characters in documentation examples, not shell execution. 'Network' findings are HTTP requests to public ENA APIs (www.ebi.ac.uk). Critical/high severity flags (SAM database, C2 keywords, weak crypto) match generic terms in documentation (sample=sam, MD5/SHA1 for checksums). No actual security risks present.

content.value_statement: Researchers need efficient access to genomic data for analysis. This skill provides programmatic access to ENA through REST APIs and FTP for retrieving DNA/RNA sequences, FASTQ files, and genome assemblies by accession number.
actual_capabilities: Search and retrieve nucleotide sequences by accession number
Query sample, study, and assembly records via ENA Portal API
Download raw sequencing reads in FASTQ format
Download bulk data via FTP or Aspera protocols
limitations: Requires network connectivity to ENA APIs (www.ebi.ac.uk)
Rate limited to 50 requests per second
Large file downloads require FTP or Aspera tools
Does not provide local data storage or caching

use_cases.title: Retrieve sequencing data for analysis
use_cases.description: Download raw FASTQ files and genome assemblies by accession number for downstream bioinformatics analysis pipelines.

use_cases.title: Search datasets by study or organism
use_cases.description: Query the ENA Portal API to find all samples, runs, or assemblies associated with a specific study or taxonomic classification.

use_cases.title: Build reproducible research workflows
use_cases.description: Integrate ENA data retrieval into automated pipelines that fetch and cite specific accessions for reproducible genomics research.

prompt_templates.title: Find samples in a study
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the ENA Portal API to search for all samples in study PRJNA[STUDY_ID]. Return the accession numbers and sample titles.
prompt_templates.scenario: Retrieving sample metadata for a specific research project

prompt_templates.title: Download sequence by accession
prompt_templates.prompt: Retrieve the nucleotide sequence for accession [ACCESSION] in FASTA format using the ENA Browser API.

prompt_templates.title: Find assemblies for organism
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all assemblies for [ORGANISM] with contig N50 >= [N50_VALUE] using the ENA Portal API.
prompt_templates.scenario: Filtering assemblies by taxonomy and quality metrics

prompt_templates.title: Bulk download workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for all read runs in study [STUDY_ID], extract the FTP URLs, and generate a script to download all files via FTP.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a bulk download script for large datasets

output_examples.input: Find assemblies for SARS-CoV-2 with assembly level chromosome
output_examples.output:
Found 5 assemblies matching criteria:
- ERR1234567: Complete Genome (MN908947.3)
- ERR2345678: Complete Genome (MW123456.1)
- ERR3456789: Assembly Level: chromosome

Access the sequences at: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/browser/api/xml/[ACCESSION]

Taxonomy ID: 562
Scientific Name: Escherichia coli
Lineage: Bacteria; Proteobacteria; Gammaproteobacteria; Enterobacterales; Enterobacteriaceae; Escherichia
Rank: Species

output_examples.input: Search for RNA-seq experiments in study PRJEB12345
output_examples.output:
Found 12 RNA-seq experiments:
- ERX123456: Paired-end, ILLUMINA
- ERX123457: Single-end, ILLUMINA
- ERX123458: Paired-end, BGI

Run accessions available for FASTQ download.

best_practices: Implement rate limiting with exponential backoff to stay within 50 requests per second
Use FTP or Aspera for downloading files larger than 100MB
Cite study and sample accessions when publishing results derived from ENA data
anti_patterns: Making individual API calls for thousands of records instead of batching
Downloading large files via HTTP when FTP/Aspera is available
Failing to handle XML parsing errors from ENA Browser API responses

faq.question: What is the difference between the ENA Portal API and Browser API?
faq.answer: The Portal API is for advanced searching and filtering across all data types. The Browser API is for direct retrieval of specific records by accession in XML format.

faq.question: How do I download large FASTQ files?
faq.answer: For files over 100MB, use FTP or Aspera protocols instead of HTTP. The ENA Portal API returns FTP URLs in search results.

faq.question: What formats can I retrieve sequences in?
faq.answer: Sequences are available in FASTA (assembled sequences), FASTQ (raw reads), XML (native format), and TSV/JSON for metadata.

faq.question: How do I find all data from a specific study?
faq.answer: Use the Portal API with query parameter study_accession=[STUDY_ID] and result type sample, read_run, or assembly as needed.

faq.question: What are the rate limits for ENA APIs?
faq.answer: All ENA APIs are limited to 50 requests per second. Exceeding this returns HTTP 429 and requires implementing backoff.

faq.question: How do I cite ENA data in my publication?
faq.answer: Include the Study/Project accession as the primary citation. Also list specific sample, run, or assembly accessions used in your analysis.
